answer_html: For example, in that case, no negative number is in the image of the function f and so no negative number can be in the image of \(f \circ g\) either.
answer_latex:
For
example, in that case, no negative number is in the image of the
function \emph{f} and so no negative number can be in the image of
$f \circ g$ either.
hints_html:
Working on part (a) and part (b) definitively helps.

In your example in part (b) f was not surjective. Can \(f \circ g\) possibly be surjective then?

hints_raw:
Working on [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH220/April 2011/Question 09 (a)|part (a)]] and [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH220/April 2011/Question 09 (b)|part (b)]] definitively helps.

In your example in [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH220/April 2011/Question 09 (b)|part (b)]] ''f'' was not surjective. Can <math>f \circ g</math> possibly be surjective then?
question: 9 (c)
sols_html: The example that we constructed in part (b) showed a case where the function f is not surjective and so it cannot be possible for \(f \circ g\) to be surjective either. For example, in that case, no negative number is in the image of the function f and so no negative number can be in the image of \(f \circ g\) either.
sols_latex:
The example that we constructed in
{part
(b)} showed a case where the function \emph{f} is not surjective and so
it cannot be possible for $f \circ g$ to be surjective either. For
example, in that case, no negative number is in the image of the
function \emph{f} and so no negative number can be in the image of
$f \circ g$ either.
sols_raw: The example that we constructed in [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH220/April 2011/Question 09 (b)|part (b)]] showed a case where the function ''f'' is not surjective and so it cannot be possible for <math>f \circ g</math> to be surjective either. For example, in that case, no negative number is in the image of the function ''f'' and so no negative number can be in the image of <math>f \circ g</math> either.
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f: A \to B \quad\text{ and }\quad g: B \to A\end{aligned}\]

be functions so that g â—‹f is a surjective function.

Prove or disprove that f â—‹g must be surjective.
statement_raw:
Let

:<math>\displaystyle f: A \to B \quad\text{  and  }\quad g: B \to A</math>

be functions so that ''g'' ○''f'' is a surjective function.

Prove or disprove that ''f'' ○''g'' must be surjective.
